title-group.article-title: Modeling and optimization of passive and semi-active suspension systems for passenger cars to improve ride comfort and isolate engine vibration

abstract.p: Suspension systems have been widely applied to vehicles, from the horse-drawn carriage with flexible leaf springs fixed at four corners, to the modern automobile with complex control algorithms. A good suspension system should provide a comfortable ride and good handling within a reasonable range of deflection. Though a passive suspension system can perform this task, its parameters are generally fixed, being chosen to achieve a certain level of the compromise between comfort and handling. The loads acting on the suspension system may be on-board and off-board, the latter being the road loads and the former being characterized mainly by vibrations induced by the engine. The primary object of this study is to improve ride comfort for a passenger car, first by optimising the values of stiffness and damping coefficient for a passive suspension system, and then by introducing a semi-active control system that makes use of sky-hook control methods.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: There are two main categories of disturbances on a vehicle, namely road and load disturbances. Road disturbances have the characteristics of large magnitude in low frequency (such as hills) and small magnitude in high frequency (such as road roughness). Load disturbances include the variation of loads induced by accelerating, braking and cornering. The design of a good suspension system is concerned with isolation of the disturbances from the car’s body. A conventional passive suspension needs to be both “soft” to insulate against road disturbances and “hard” to insulate against load disturbances. Therefore, suspension design is a compromise between these two goals. There are two main categories of suspension systems, namely passive and active suspension systems (Gillespie, 1992). A passive suspension, which means there is no energy source in the system, provides a simpler and cheaper way of suspension design at the expense of performance limitations of the type described above. On the other hand, active suspensions incorporate extra energy sources to refine the compromise.

In suspension design for full-car models it has been found advantageous to decompose the motion into bounce, pitch and roll components for the vehicle body, and additionally warp for the wheels that are in contact with the road (Fleuren, 2009). This study will also exploit such transformations. A generalized nonlinear model is formulated for the dynamic analysis of suspension seats with passive and semi-active dampers. The model incorporates forces arising from interactions with the elastic limit stops, a linear suspension spring and nonlinear damping force for passive, semi-active and active dampers, while the contribution due to biodynamics of the human operator is considered to be negligible. The semi-active dampers are characterized by force generators in accordance with the control laws based upon suspension mass velocity. In the present study, the input parameters considered are road roughness, speed, load conditions and the output parameter is driver seat accelerations. Then a non-traditional optimization technique, namely genetic algorithm, has been used to derive the optimized process parameters of the unsuspended cabin tractor semitrailer.

sec.title: 1.1. ISO weighting functions
sec.p: Because of its subjective nature, ride comfort is difficult to assess. Nevertheless, many recent research results have shows a minimum tolerance (maximum sensitivity) of the human body to vertical vibrations in the frequency range between 4 and 8 Hz. This sensitivity is the result of vertical resonances of the abdominal cavity. The overall ride comfort including the human vibration sensitivity will be calculated according to ISO 2631-1 (1997) weighting functions.

sec.title: 2.1. Quarter-car model
sec.p:
In conventional suspension systems, each wheel incorporates the same control system and the values of stiffness and damping coefficients are similar if not equal. Therefore, only one wheel needs be evaluated to get a response that will be loosely indicative of the response of the entire suspension system to loads. Quarter-car vehicle models are widely used in automotive engineering due to the simplicity with which they can be analyzed and the qualitatively correct information they provide, at least in the initial design stages. The model used (Figure 1) initially incorporated one sprung mass, one unsprung mass and the driver’s seat. The equations of motion can easily be put in the classical matrix form as follows, (1)Mx··+Cx·+Kx=f(t)
Figure 1.
Quarter-car model.

The vector f(t) includes the forcing terms, arising from the road roughness. In particular, the vehicle is assumed to travel with a constant horizontal velocity v0 over a road. Here, this profile is represented by a random process with a statistical distribution, which is consistent with measurements of typical road profiles (Dodds and Robson, 1973). Therefore, the forcing vector is expressed in the form (2)f(t)=M-1·(feng+f0+fg)

sec.title: 2.2. Half-car model
sec.p: Though the quarter-car model is quite representative of the vibration response of the entire car, it is lacking in accuracy when the effect of vibrations on the human body is to be studied. Pitch motion can be incorporated to give a more real model by using a 6-degree-of-freedom longitudinal half-car, also known as the pitch plane model because the car is assumed to be symmetric about the longitudinal axis and either of the halves is assumed to be an accurate representation of a real car. Here too, the forcing function, f(t) is composed of the road roughness, gravity and engine unbalanced forces. The sprung mass, unsprung masses, passenger and seat, engine mass and all the connecting springs and damping elements have been included in the model. The equations of motion are written in the classical matrix form as in equation (1). Here too, the forcing function, f(t) is made up of the road roughness, gravity and engine unbalanced forces.

sec.title: 2.3. Full-car model
sec.p: Lateral accelerations (about the roll axis) play an important role in the ride comfort of a vehicle. But these cannot be modeled using a half-car suspension system. For this reason, a 12-degree-of-freedom full car model, which incorporated roll vibrations, was required to be made, and the quarter-car and half-car models made earlier, though correct and accurate in serving their purpose, will not be discussed further in this study.

The model is a close approximation of a real production car with the most commonly used suspension layout, independent McPherson struts in the front and a dependent multi-link suspension at the rear. It consists of four unsprung masses, a sprung mass, four seats for four passengers mounted separately on the chassis, and an engine mass for a four cylinder in-line engine which produces the unbalanced secondary forces of the piston motion.

The model used in this study included damping coefficients for the tyres, an engine mass and four seats for the passengers. Also, instead of the independent suspension in the rear as shown in this schematic, the model made use of a trailing arm with twist-beam suspension for the rear. The parameters of the full-car used in the model are tabulated in Table 1. The dynamics equations are written in matrix form as in equation (1). The forcing vector used for the passive suspension model was the same as shown in equation (3), and the forcing vector used for the active suspension model was, (3)f(t)=inv(M)*(feng+froad+fg+fsky)

sec.title: 2.4. Semi-active suspension control
sec.p: The mechanical model used for simulation uses a method known as ideal “sky-hook” control and presents certain advantages over the models with conventional suspension. In its simplest form, this model possesses linear characteristics. However, since it is impossible to materialize this type of suspension, an appropriate control strategy has to be applied, modifying its characteristics. According to previous studies on the subject, the behavior of the sky-hook model is approached by applying the control force between the two masses of the system. (4)Fsky=(Csky+Cs)x·s-Csx·u

The dynamical systems resulting after the application of either the passive bilinear or the semi-active control strategies are strongly nonlinear, since the value of the suspension damping coefficient changes at certain points. Moreover, a strongly nonliear effect is introduced even for the systems with linear characteristics, when the wheel is allowed to separate and lift off the ground temporarily. This phenomenon, known as wheel hop, causes drastic changes in the overall dynamic response of the vehicle (Verros and Natsiavas, 2001). The phenomenon of wheel-hop was not included in the model used for simulation. The modeling and simulation were done by using Csky = 50000 Nms−1 (Verros et al., 2000). The controller was initially developed for the quarter-car model and then implemented in the full-car as given below: (5)Fsky=(Csky+Crf+Clf+Clr+Crr)x·s +Crrx·urr+Crfx·urf+Clrx·ulr+Clfx·ulf

sec.title: 2.5. Road profile
sec.p:
A road can be considered as an infinite cam with the profile of mixed harmonic sine waves and random white noise, and the wheel of the vehicle may be considered a follower with freedom to move in the vertical direction only.The road profiles used in this simulation were composed of pseudo-random excitations drawn from the standard open normal distribution from open intervals (0,1) suitably scaled to represent roads of different roughness indices.The model was assumed to run on roads whose profile elevation varied from 0 mm to 50 mm. A random profile was generated (Figure 2), with the values of elevation in a Gaussian distribution about the mean value. Random profiles whose mean elevation values ranged from 10 mm to 250 mm were created and used for the study. In the subsequent parts of this dissertation, we will only discuss a profile of mean elevation 50 mm, which was found to be reasonably accurate in representing slightly worn roads. In addition to a random road profile, a bump was also modeled for the simulation to study combined roll and pitch characteristics of the suspension system. The road profile that will be discussed in this study is shown in Figure 2. Figure 2.

sec.title: 3. Optimization
sec.p:
The suspension stiffnesses and damping coefficients of the semi-active model were optimized for ride comfort by using a genetic algorithm (Verros et al. 2005). The objective of this optimization is to minimize the accelerations experienced in the seat. Optimization of the suspension parameters was done for a random road profile. The optimized values of the suspension variables are tabulated in Table 2. The fitness function optimized for was the bounce acceleration of the sprung mass, which is plotted in Figure 3. Table 2.

sec.title: 4. Results and discussion
sec.p: The model was created mainly to serve as a test bed for vibration analysis to help in the improvement of ride comfort, and to serve as a platform for further research in active suspension control. The former is as much a function of the road profile and onboard disturbances as it is of the vibration isolation characteristics of the suspension system. Vibrations caused by the engine are the biggest onboard influence on the ride comfort of the vehicle. For the simulation, a four cylinder in-line engine, running at 4,500 rpm was used. The unbalanced forces were calculated as (6)Feng=mrw2(r/l)sin(2wt)

sec.title: 4.1. Ride comfort weighing functions (Dundurs, 2001)
sec.p: ISO 2631-1(1997) recommends using the vibration total value (av) for predicting the human health risk and overall weighted total root mean square (RMS) accelerations. Each frequency-weighted RMS acceleration at the driver seat interface (x-, y- and z- axes) is used to find the resultant, which is the overall weighted total RMS acceleration, av: (7)av=((kxax)2+(kyay)2+(kzaz)2)

The factors kx(=1.4), ky(=1.4) and kz(=1) are the ratios of values of longitudinal and transverse curves of equal response in the most sensitive human response ranges. Annex B of ISO 2631/1 provides the guidelines for assessment of whole-body vibration with respect to health. The health guidance caution zone is indicated by dotted lines in Figure B.1 of Annex B of ISO 2631/1. The RMS value of the frequency-weighted acceleration can be compared with the zone shown in Figure B.1 at the duration of the expected daily exposure (Paddan and Griffin, 2002). Through the course of this dissertation, the overall weighted total RMS acceleration data were compared with the lower bound of the zone given by equation B.2 in Figure B.1 of ISO 2631/1 (Figure 4). The full-car suspension models with sky-hook control were then simulated using these values to give the results shown in Table 2. Figure 4.

sec.p:

sec.title: 4.3. Acceleration response
sec.p: Low frequencies (<5 Hz): The pitch-acceleration shows no peaks in the low frequency range 0.1 Hz to 4 Hz. Looking at the passenger’s seat, the x and z-accelerations in the low frequency range are negligibly low. The peak amplitude of effective accelerations at the seats for this frequency range is not very different for the passive and semi-active systems.

High frequencies (>5 Hz): High amplitude roll and pitch motions of the sprung mass will cause larger vertical accelerations of the seats, exacerbating the discomfort of the passengers. Another set of peaks occurs at 75–80 Hz. These are not of much consequence so far as ride comfort is concerned as they do not adversely affect the human body (Alphin et al. 2010; Oborne, 1977; Seidel and Heide, 1986).

sec.title: 4.3.1. Seat acceleration
sec.p:
For the passive suspension system (Figure 8), a set of peaks of amplitudes 0.0578 ms−2 and 0.061 ms−2 occur in the range 25 Hz to 79 Hz. These are completely negated and replaced with one peak of amplitude 0.021 ms−2 by using the semi-active suspension system. Figure 8.

sec.p:
Similarly, roll acceleration is contained to a peak value of 0.028 ms−2 at 48 Hz by semi-active suspension control, as compared to 0.057 ms−2 at 57 Hz with the passive system. The acceleration responses (Table 3), plotted in the frequency domain as amplitude spectra, are shown in Figure 9. sec.title: 5. Conclusions
sec.p: Active suspension designs must resolve the inherent tradeoffs between ride quality, handling, suspension travel and power consumption. According to these aims, an optimization law is developed for a suspension system control based on the states’ estimation and states’ prediction of a nonlinear half-car model. The proposed optimal nonlinear control law is given in an analytical closed form that is easy to solve, and online optimization is not necessary (Tiemessen et al. 2007). The proposed controller was applied on a full-car model and compared with a passive suspension system. The obtained results demonstrated that the body acceleration and wheel deflection of our proposed controller was an improvement over the passive system in terms of weighted seat acceleration values.

Optimization of the stiffness and damping coefficients of the suspension system was carried out and the results were found to have improved the ride comfort of the vehicle. This improvement can be quantified in terms of time taken to attain steady-state vibrations. Initially, steady-state vibrations of the seat were attained in a time period of 4.34 seconds for the semi-active model with sky-hook control. The use of damping coefficient and stiffness values obtained as results of optimization has reduced this time to 1.882 seconds, a reduction in time of 56.4%

sec.title: 5.1. Suggestions for future research
sec.p: Vehicle handling is as much a function of the suspension system as is ride comfort. Inclusion of anti-roll, anti-dive and anti-lift components in the full-car model may be done. This dissertation was done under the assumption that the tyres are always in contact with the road. To make the model more real, the phenomenon of wheel hop may be included. Also, multi-objective optimization for ride comfort and vehicle handling may be done.
